A meeting OF the Friends Of Agriculture and
Domestic Manufactures of the state of Della
ware, was held. pursuant to public notice,
yesterday, 27th, at the Town Hall in tllis
Borough. Several resolutions were adopt
ed, expressing sense OF the Importance OF
encouraging these great objects Of national
concern; after which tha following named
gentlemen we're appointed Delegates to meet
the Convention at Harrisburg, viz: II. M.
Ridgley, Esq, L. M'Lane, Esq. f. l. Dupont,
Esq. James X. Black, Esq. James Candy,
VIM. w. Young, Caleb Kirk, DR.. Naudain'


Our paper having gone TO press before
the regular proceedings of the meeting could
be obtained. we shall not be able TO publish
them before next week.

Mauch Chunck railway, and went nine mile IN
ten minutes. Fortunately it encountered nothing
in its course, and did no injury.

THE undersigned having been appointed BY
the Borough Council Committe to receive Pro-
posals for Loan not exceeding $4,000 Dollars,
for the purpose of supplying the Borough with
water, at a rate of interest not exceeding five
per centum per annum, payable semi-annually,
and reimbursable at the end of 90 years from the
4th of July, 1827-Notice is therefore hereby
given, that such proposals will now be received
by the undersigned at any time after the present
date, for taking said Loan.


JAMES BROBSON, I


JAMES GARDNER,


JOSEPH GRUBB,


VIM. LARKIN,


Committee.
June 18th, 1897. 39-tf.
Borough loan.

Wha, inc extricable confusion mus, tie world
have been in, but for the variety which we find
to obtain in the faces, the voices, anil the hand
writings of men. No security Of person, ofpos-
session, no justice between men. no distinction
between good and bad, friends and foes, father
and child, husband and wife, male and female. -
Ali would have been exposed TO malice, fraud,
and lust. But now every mans face can distin-
guish him in the light, his voice in the dark, and
his hand writings can speak for him though alb
sent, and be his witness to all generations nid
this happen by chance, or is it not manifest, a,
well a. admirable, indication Of a divine supeiil-

The whale noticed in our last, as having pass
cd the Portsmouth bridge over the Piscataqua
river has been taken. lie was harpooned on
Tuesday evening, and continued towing the two
boats attached to him till Wednesday morning at
z o'clock, when he was despatched, in the view
Of thousands who fiocked to see him.


The Portsmouth Advertiser says, "the length
of tic whale is about 50 feet, and its breadth a.
bout l6 feet, his head is shaped like that of a
horse, and he differs from all others that have
been seen by those acquainted with that species
of fish. His motion was undulatory, and it is the
opinion Of Col. Decatur [who captured him that
this is the very Sea Serpent which has So long
been a visitor on our coast"

Hugh King, soldier, was executed at ST.
Louis, on the 27th May. for the murder Of Mar
t;u G.een. At the place o. execution he deliver
cd neat speech. and among other adnontoFy
remarks arc the following:


II can trace most Of my avert acts of wicked
hess 10 iutcnperancc. The influence OF ardent
spirits has been to destroy my reason for the time
being. often had felnt, and sometimes no
recollection, of things that transpircd when |
was partially intoxicated have no recollection
Of Killing Sergeant Green. nor Of firing a gun
that day, nor OF many things which are said to
have transpired about that time. had been for
scver, daysmost Of the time under the influence
of liquors yet do not plead thi' as any instlfica-
ton ofmy crime. From the testimony otothers,
can have no doubt but that shot Green, tho
never harboured ill-will against him. Accord
ing to the laws of God and my country, have
forfeited my life.

Some time after the conclusion Of the A.
merican Revolution, young American was
present in a British play house; all inter
Jude was performed in ridicule OF his coun-
trymen. A number of American officers be-
ing introduced in tattered uniforms and bare
footed, the question was put to them, sever
allv, "What was your trade before you en-
tered the army?" One answered tailor;
another cobler. The wit Of the piece was
to banter them for not keeping themselves
IN clothes and shoes; but before that could
be expressed. the American exclaimed trem
the gallery: Great Britain was beaten by
taiIors and coblers huzza" Even the Prime
minister himself, who was present, could not
help smiling, amidst general peal ofiaush-
ter

patient would get well Immediately! The event
however, did not reaizc the poor mans cxpec
tations: for although the knife was burnt to
coal, the wound thad been instrumental in in
Aseting terminated fatally il a few days after
wards

Two first rate steamboats, have been recently
constructed on the Rhine, the machinerv OF
which has been particularly arranged to afford
safety to passengers. With the machinery is
Connected piece of mechanism which promises
perfect safety. This is an hydraulic press, by
Which the boiler is every day put TO the test


me force of this press is proigious; it can ca
ss.lly crush the most solid boiler. ny the hydrau-
NC test the boiler must be able to support pres
alTe of 165 pounds to the square inch, and as IN
@alhary cases it IS sufficient that it should resist
iorce of / that amount, that is Is to say OF %
pounds there is no danger to be feared Be
sres this, there are adapted to the boilers sever,
aplugs oflcad, which by too great degree Of
neat are melted, and pour torrents OF water up
oh the fire. On the rudder is fixed a barometer,
provided with kind of quadrant, upon which
ran De seen the extent of the pressure at any mo

Mr. Diehl, the supcrcargo ofthe New Jersey,
at Philadelphia from Canton, states that the re-
bellion which had for some time been raging IN
parts Of the Chinese Emperor's dominion, had
assumed very serious aspect, and was spread
ing at the date ofthe last advces. The Empe'
ror had recently made considerable drafts on the
Salt and Hong Merchants, for the means Of car.
ryinr on the war. 1t was doubtful what effect
the insurrection would have on the coming Tea
Crop.

full articles.article:
A meeting OF the Friends Of Agriculture and
Domestic Manufactures of the state of Della
ware, was held. pursuant to public notice,
yesterday, 27th, at the Town Hall in tllis
Borough. Several resolutions were adopt
ed, expressing sense OF the Importance OF
encouraging these great objects Of national
concern; after which tha following named
gentlemen we're appointed Delegates to meet
the Convention at Harrisburg, viz: II. M.
Ridgley, Esq, L. M'Lane, Esq. f. l. Dupont,
Esq. James X. Black, Esq. James Candy,
VIM. w. Young, Caleb Kirk, DR.. Naudain'


Our paper having gone TO press before
the regular proceedings of the meeting could
be obtained. we shall not be able TO publish
them before next week.

A car loaded with coal got loose lately on the

ten minutes. Fortunately it encountered nothing
in its course, and did no injury.

full articles.headline: Borough loan.
full articles.article:
THE undersigned having been appointed BY
the Borough Council Committe to receive Pro-
posals for Loan not exceeding $4,000 Dollars,
for the purpose of supplying the Borough with
water, at a rate of interest not exceeding five
per centum per annum, payable semi-annually,
and reimbursable at the end of 90 years from the
4th of July, 1827-Notice is therefore hereby
given, that such proposals will now be received
by the undersigned at any time after the present
date, for taking said Loan.


JAMES BROBSON, I


JAMES GARDNER,


JOSEPH GRUBB,


VIM. LARKIN,


Committee.
June 18th, 1897. 39-tf.

full articles.headline: PROVIDENCE.
full articles.article:
Wha, inc extricable confusion mus, tie world
have been in, but for the variety which we find
to obtain in the faces, the voices, anil the hand
writings of men. No security Of person, ofpos-
session, no justice between men. no distinction
between good and bad, friends and foes, father
and child, husband and wife, male and female. -
Ali would have been exposed TO malice, fraud,
and lust. But now every mans face can distin-
guish him in the light, his voice in the dark, and
his hand writings can speak for him though alb
sent, and be his witness to all generations nid
this happen by chance, or is it not manifest, a,
well a. admirable, indication Of a divine supeiil-
'cndenee

full articles.headline: From The .Salem Gazette. Juno Is.
full articles.article:
The whale noticed in our last, as having pass
cd the Portsmouth bridge over the Piscataqua
river has been taken. lie was harpooned on
Tuesday evening, and continued towing the two
boats attached to him till Wednesday morning at
z o'clock, when he was despatched, in the view
Of thousands who fiocked to see him.


The Portsmouth Advertiser says, "the length
of tic whale is about 50 feet, and its breadth a.
bout l6 feet, his head is shaped like that of a
horse, and he differs from all others that have
been seen by those acquainted with that species
of fish. His motion was undulatory, and it is the
opinion Of Col. Decatur [who captured him that
this is the very Sea Serpent which has So long
been a visitor on our coast"

Wilmington, June 27, 1927.

patIos.-Not long since, an eminent lawyer OF
Ohio, closed pathetic harangue to a jury in the
following strain:


sAnd now the shades Of night had shrouded
+he earth in darkness.-All nature lay wrapped
in solemn thought when these defendant ruf-
fans came rushing like mighty torrent from the
hills down on the abodes of peace--broke open
the plaintiffs door--separated the weeping mo-
ther from her screeching children--and took a
way my clients rife. gentlemen of the jury, tor
which we charge fifteen dollars"

full articles.headline: Cure for IMteMpeYance.
full articles.article:
The Wilmington Society for Suppressing
Intemperance, has received a few doses OF

bers, of N. York, which may be had on aP-
plication to James Watson, Thos Nicer
klc, or VIM. A. Mendenhall, Confidential
Committee; who may at any time be found
at their respective places OF business.

Operations are commenced for building Dry
Dock in the Navy Yard at Charlcstown, under
the law passed at the last session of Congress
The engineer entered upon his duties in the
yard ON the lst inst and it is said TO be the inten
ton of the executive to hasten the completion Of
the Dock With all possible despatch.

A most dangerous and extensive iusurrection
OF the blacks was detected at Macon few days
since. They had banded together to the num-
her Of 800, and supposed to be instigated and
headed by French emgrant from the Missssip-
p His slaves were in the plot They had only
arrested one Of the rebels The whole of the
Others, with the Frenchman, have made their
escape.

At Alstead, in New-Hampshirc, a large major
ny Of the soldiers assembled for an annual train
innB voted that they would not drink ardent spi-
i'S, and maintained this profession Of sobriety by
Practice pa1i This is an example worthy of re-
marx and imitation, as trainings too often pro-
auce rlotous and dsorderly scenes IN social So
elety' rather than any improvement in military
tactics Or subordination.

full articles.headline: iTTF.ipE.RA,<CE,
full articles.article:
Hugh King, soldier, was executed at ST.
Louis, on the 27th May. for the murder Of Mar
t;u G.een. At the place o. execution he deliver
cd neat speech. and among other adnontoFy
remarks arc the following:


II can trace most Of my avert acts of wicked
hess 10 iutcnperancc. The influence OF ardent
spirits has been to destroy my reason for the time
being. often had felnt, and sometimes no
recollection, of things that transpircd when |
was partially intoxicated have no recollection
Of Killing Sergeant Green. nor Of firing a gun
that day, nor OF many things which are said to
have transpired about that time. had been for
scver, daysmost Of the time under the influence
of liquors yet do not plead thi' as any instlfica-
ton ofmy crime. From the testimony otothers,
can have no doubt but that shot Green, tho
never harboured ill-will against him. Accord
ing to the laws of God and my country, have
forfeited my life.

kdnapper, whose arrival in New-York from
Boston, under arrest, WAS announced in this pa
per last week, was tfied at Philadelphia on Sat
urdsy week and convicted, Judge King sen
tenced him to tortY-tlUo years Imprisonment, and
10 pay a fine of 1000 dollars and costs Of prose
cution.

Mr.-Thc New Monthly Magazine gives the
following method of obtaining flowers Of differ.
ent colours on the same stem


Split small twiS OF elder lengthways, anihav-
ing scraped out the pi'h, fill each Of the apart
ments with seeds Of flowers Of different sorts,
but which blossom about tho same time--sur-
round them With mould, and then tying together
the two bits OF wool, plaat the whole in pot
hed w,h earth, properly prepared. HE stems
OF thc different flowers MA thu, le 50 inco.po
rated as to exhibit to the eye only onc stem,
throwing oQt branches Covered With flowers 4
nalogous u tie seed Which produced them.

Some time after the conclusion Of the A.
merican Revolution, young American was
present in a British play house; all inter
Jude was performed in ridicule OF his coun-
trymen. A number of American officers be-
ing introduced in tattered uniforms and bare
footed, the question was put to them, sever
allv, "What was your trade before you en-
tered the army?" One answered tailor;
another cobler. The wit Of the piece was
to banter them for not keeping themselves
IN clothes and shoes; but before that could
be expressed. the American exclaimed trem
the gallery: Great Britain was beaten by
taiIors and coblers huzza" Even the Prime
minister himself, who was present, could not
help smiling, amidst general peal ofiaush-
ter

Redding, indicted for the murder of VIM Blair

coal, the wound thad been instrumental in in

wards

ror had recently made considerable drafts on the
